content: There is no text provided in the prev_chunk, so I cannot generate a condensed text chunk for the curr_chunk. The Congress recognizes the significance of the Brown v. Board of Education decision, the integration of the "Little Rock Nine" at Central High School, and the historical importance of Central High School itself. The Little Rock Central High School was designated as a national historic landmark in 1982 for its role in the civil rights movement and desegregation of public schools in the South. The purpose of this Act is to preserve and interpret the school's significance in the integration of public schools and the development of civil rights in the United States. Establishment of Central High School National Historic Site. The Little Rock Central High School national historic site is established as a unit of the National Park System in Arkansas. The Secretary of the Interior will administer the site in accordance with relevant laws. Cooperative agreements can be made with public and private agencies. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with public and private agencies, organizations, and institutions to further the purposes of the Act. A general management plan for the historic site must be prepared within 2 years. The Secretary shall consult with the Little Rock School District to ensure the site does not interfere with the educational use of Central High School. The Secretary is authorized to acquire property for the site. The Secretary is authorized to acquire property for the historic site, including lands and interests within its boundaries, with consent from the owner. Lands owned by the State of Arkansas or a political subdivision may only be acquired through donation or exchange. SEC. 3. DESEGREGATION IN PUBLIC EDUCATION THEME STUDY. The Secretary is required to prepare a national historic landmark theme study on the history of desegregation in public education within 2 years. The study will identify sites that commemorate key events in the movement for racial desegregation. It will also establish linkages between these sites and existing units of the National Park System. The Secretary is mandated to prepare a national historic landmark theme study on desegregation in public education within 2 years. This study will identify key sites, establish linkages with existing National Park System units, and recommend cooperative arrangements for preservation and interpretation. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with educational institutions, public history organizations, or civil rights organizations to ensure scholarly standards are met. The theme study will be part of the general management plan for the Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Such sums as necessary are authorized to carry out this Act.
